trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure virtual machines (VMs) with SQL Server can help lower the cost of a high availability and disaster recovery (HADR) database solution.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure virtual machines (VMs) with SQL Server can help lower the cost of a high availability and disaster recovery (HADR) database solution.

trans-unit.source: Most SQL Server HADR solutions are supported in Azure virtual machines, both as Azure-only and as hybrid solutions.
trans-unit.target: Most SQL Server HADR solutions are supported in Azure virtual machines, both as Azure-only and as hybrid solutions.

trans-unit.source: In an Azure-only solution, the entire HADR system runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In an Azure-only solution, the entire HADR system runs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In a hybrid configuration, part of the solution runs in Azure and the other part runs on-premises in your organization.
trans-unit.target: In a hybrid configuration, part of the solution runs in Azure and the other part runs on-premises in your organization.

trans-unit.source: The flexibility of the Azure environment enables you to move partially or completely to Azure to satisfy the budget and HADR requirements of your SQL Server database systems.
trans-unit.target: The flexibility of the Azure environment enables you to move partially or completely to Azure to satisfy the budget and HADR requirements of your SQL Server database systems.

trans-unit.source: Understanding the need for an HADR solution
trans-unit.target: Understanding the need for an HADR solution

trans-unit.source: It is up to you to ensure that your database system possesses the HADR capabilities that the service-level agreement (SLA) requires.
trans-unit.target: It is up to you to ensure that your database system possesses the HADR capabilities that the service-level agreement (SLA) requires.

trans-unit.source: The fact that Azure provides high availability mechanisms, such as service healing for cloud services and failure recovery detection for the Virtual Machines, does not itself guarantee you can meet the desired SLA.
trans-unit.target: The fact that Azure provides high availability mechanisms, such as service healing for cloud services and failure recovery detection for the Virtual Machines, does not itself guarantee you can meet the desired SLA.

trans-unit.source: These mechanisms protect the high availability of the VMs but not the high availability of SQL Server running inside the VMs.
trans-unit.target: These mechanisms protect the high availability of the VMs but not the high availability of SQL Server running inside the VMs.

trans-unit.source: It is possible for the SQL Server instance to fail while the VM is online and healthy.
trans-unit.target: It is possible for the SQL Server instance to fail while the VM is online and healthy.

trans-unit.source: Moreover, even the high availability mechanisms provided by Azure allow for downtime of the VMs due to events such as recovery from software or hardware failures and operating system upgrades.
trans-unit.target: Moreover, even the high availability mechanisms provided by Azure allow for downtime of the VMs due to events such as recovery from software or hardware failures and operating system upgrades.

trans-unit.source: In addition, Geo Redundant Storage (GRS) in Azure, which is implemented with a feature called geo-replication, may not be an adequate disaster recovery solution for your databases.
trans-unit.target: In addition, Geo Redundant Storage (GRS) in Azure, which is implemented with a feature called geo-replication, may not be an adequate disaster recovery solution for your databases.

trans-unit.source: Because geo-replication sends data asynchronously, recent updates can be lost in the event of disaster.
trans-unit.target: Because geo-replication sends data asynchronously, recent updates can be lost in the event of disaster.

trans-unit.source: More information regarding geo-replication limitations are covered in the <link><linkText>Geo-replication not supported for data and log files on separate disks</linkText><title></title></link> section.
trans-unit.target: More information regarding geo-replication limitations are covered in the <link><linkText>Geo-replication not supported for data and log files on separate disks</linkText><title></title></link> section.

trans-unit.source: Important considerations for SQL Server HADR in Azure
trans-unit.target: Important considerations for SQL Server HADR in Azure

trans-unit.source: Azure VMs, storage, and networking have different operational characteristics than an on-premises, non-virtualized IT infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: Azure VMs, storage, and networking have different operational characteristics than an on-premises, non-virtualized IT infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: A successful implementation of a HADR SQL Server solution in Azure requires that you understand these differences and design your solution to accommodate them.
trans-unit.target: A successful implementation of a HADR SQL Server solution in Azure requires that you understand these differences and design your solution to accommodate them.

trans-unit.source: High availability nodes in an availability set
trans-unit.target: High availability nodes in an availability set

trans-unit.source: Availability sets in Azure enable you to place the high availability nodes into separate Fault Domains (FDs) and Update Domains (UDs).
trans-unit.target: Availability sets in Azure enable you to place the high availability nodes into separate Fault Domains (FDs) and Update Domains (UDs).

trans-unit.source: For Azure VMs to be placed in the same availability set, you must deploy them in the same cloud service.
trans-unit.target: For Azure VMs to be placed in the same availability set, you must deploy them in the same cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Only nodes in the same cloud service can participate in the same availability set.
trans-unit.target: Only nodes in the same cloud service can participate in the same availability set.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Manage the Availability of Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Manage the Availability of Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: WSFC cluster behavior in Azure networking
trans-unit.target: WSFC cluster behavior in Azure networking

trans-unit.source: The non-RFC-compliant DHCP service in Azure can cause the creation of certain WSFC cluster configurations to fail, due to the cluster network name being assigned a duplicate IP address, such as the same IP address as one of the cluster nodes.
trans-unit.target: The non-RFC-compliant DHCP service in Azure can cause the creation of certain WSFC cluster configurations to fail, due to the cluster network name being assigned a duplicate IP address, such as the same IP address as one of the cluster nodes.

trans-unit.source: This is an issue when you implement AlwaysOn Availability Groups, which depends on the WSFC feature.
trans-unit.target: This is an issue when you implement AlwaysOn Availability Groups, which depends on the WSFC feature.

trans-unit.source: Consider the scenario when a two-node cluster is created and brought online:
trans-unit.target: Consider the scenario when a two-node cluster is created and brought online:

trans-unit.source: The cluster comes online, then NODE1 requests a dynamically assigned IP address for the cluster network name.
trans-unit.target: The cluster comes online, then NODE1 requests a dynamically assigned IP address for the cluster network name.

trans-unit.source: No IP address other than NODE1’s own IP address is given by the DHCP service, since the DHCP service recognizes that the request comes from NODE1 itself.
trans-unit.target: No IP address other than NODE1’s own IP address is given by the DHCP service, since the DHCP service recognizes that the request comes from NODE1 itself.

trans-unit.source: Windows detects that a duplicate address is assigned both to NODE1 and to the cluster network name, and the default cluster group fails to come online.
trans-unit.target: Windows detects that a duplicate address is assigned both to NODE1 and to the cluster network name, and the default cluster group fails to come online.

trans-unit.source: The default cluster group moves to NODE2, which treats NODE1’s IP address as the cluster IP address and brings the default cluster group online.
trans-unit.target: The default cluster group moves to NODE2, which treats NODE1’s IP address as the cluster IP address and brings the default cluster group online.

trans-unit.source: When NODE2 attempts to establish connectivity with NODE1, packets directed at NODE1 never leave NODE2 because it resolves NODE1’s IP address to itself.
trans-unit.target: When NODE2 attempts to establish connectivity with NODE1, packets directed at NODE1 never leave NODE2 because it resolves NODE1’s IP address to itself.

trans-unit.source: NODE2 cannot establish connectivity with NODE1, then loses quorum and shuts down the cluster.
trans-unit.target: NODE2 cannot establish connectivity with NODE1, then loses quorum and shuts down the cluster.

trans-unit.source: In the meantime, NODE1 can send packets to NODE2, but NODE2 cannot reply.
trans-unit.target: In the meantime, NODE1 can send packets to NODE2, but NODE2 cannot reply.

trans-unit.source: NODE1 loses quorum and shuts down the cluster.
trans-unit.target: NODE1 loses quorum and shuts down the cluster.

trans-unit.source: This scenario can be avoided by assigning an unused static IP address, such as a link-local IP address like 169.254.1.1, to the cluster network name in order to bring the cluster network name online.
trans-unit.target: This scenario can be avoided by assigning an unused static IP address, such as a link-local IP address like 169.254.1.1, to the cluster network name in order to bring the cluster network name online.

trans-unit.source: To simplify this process, see <link><linkText>Configuring Windows Failover Cluster in Azure for AlwaysOn Availability Groups</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To simplify this process, see <link><linkText>Configuring Windows Failover Cluster in Azure for AlwaysOn Availability Groups</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Availability group listener support
trans-unit.target: Availability group listener support

trans-unit.source: Availability group listeners are supported on Azure VMs running Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, and Windows Server 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: Availability group listeners are supported on Azure VMs running Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, and Windows Server 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: This support is made possible by the use of load-balanced endpoints with direct server return (DSR) enabled on the Azure VMs that are availability group nodes.
trans-unit.target: This support is made possible by the use of load-balanced endpoints with direct server return (DSR) enabled on the Azure VMs that are availability group nodes.

trans-unit.source: You must follow special configuration steps for the listeners to work for both client applications that are running in Azure as well as those running on-premises.
trans-unit.target: You must follow special configuration steps for the listeners to work for both client applications that are running in Azure as well as those running on-premises.

trans-unit.source: Clients must connect to the listener from a machine that is not in the same cloud service as the AlwaysOn Availability Group nodes.
trans-unit.target: Clients must connect to the listener from a machine that is not in the same cloud service as the AlwaysOn Availability Group nodes.

trans-unit.source: If the Availability Group spans multiple Azure subnets (such as a deployment that crosses Azure regions), the client connection string must include "MultisubnetFailover=True".
trans-unit.target: If the Availability Group spans multiple Azure subnets (such as a deployment that crosses Azure regions), the client connection string must include "MultisubnetFailover=True".

trans-unit.source: This results in parallel connection attempts to the replicas in the different subnets.
trans-unit.target: This results in parallel connection attempts to the replicas in the different subnets.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on setting up a listener, see <link><linkText>Configure an ILB listener for AlwaysOn Availability Groups in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on setting up a listener, see <link><linkText>Configure an ILB listener for AlwaysOn Availability Groups in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Network latency in hybrid IT
trans-unit.target: Network latency in hybrid IT

trans-unit.source: You should deploy your HADR solution with the assumption that there may be periods of time with high network latency between your on-premises network and Azure.
trans-unit.target: You should deploy your HADR solution with the assumption that there may be periods of time with high network latency between your on-premises network and Azure.

trans-unit.source: When deploying replicas to Azure, you should use asynchronous commit instead of synchronous commit for the synchronization mode.
trans-unit.target: When deploying replicas to Azure, you should use asynchronous commit instead of synchronous commit for the synchronization mode.

trans-unit.source: When deploying database mirroring servers both on-premises and in Azure, use the high performance mode instead of the high safety mode.
trans-unit.target: When deploying database mirroring servers both on-premises and in Azure, use the high performance mode instead of the high safety mode.

trans-unit.source: Geo replication support
trans-unit.target: Geo replication support

trans-unit.source: Geo-replication in Azure disks does not support the data file and log file of the same database to be stored on separate disks.
trans-unit.target: Geo-replication in Azure disks does not support the data file and log file of the same database to be stored on separate disks.

trans-unit.source: GRS replicates changes on each disk independently and asynchronously.
trans-unit.target: GRS replicates changes on each disk independently and asynchronously.

trans-unit.source: This mechanism guarantees the write order within a single disk on the geo-replicated copy, but not across geo-replicated copies of multiple disks.
trans-unit.target: This mechanism guarantees the write order within a single disk on the geo-replicated copy, but not across geo-replicated copies of multiple disks.

trans-unit.source: If you configure a database to store its data file and its log file on separate disks, the recovered disks after a disaster may contain a more up-to-date copy of the data file than the log file, which breaks the write-ahead log in SQL Server and the ACID properties of transactions.
trans-unit.target: If you configure a database to store its data file and its log file on separate disks, the recovered disks after a disaster may contain a more up-to-date copy of the data file than the log file, which breaks the write-ahead log in SQL Server and the ACID properties of transactions.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have the option to disable geo-replication on the storage account, you should keep all data and log files for a given database on the same disk.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have the option to disable geo-replication on the storage account, you should keep all data and log files for a given database on the same disk.

trans-unit.source: If you must use more than one disk due to the size of the database, you need to deploy one of the disaster recovery solutions listed above to ensure data redundancy.
trans-unit.target: If you must use more than one disk due to the size of the database, you need to deploy one of the disaster recovery solutions listed above to ensure data redundancy.
